resources.string: Android Tűzfal: Hiba a tűzfal engedélyezésekor!
Android Tűzfal: Tűzfal le van tiltva!
Android Tűzfal: Hiba a tűzfal letiltásakor!
Hiba az egyedi script mentése közben
Add meg a saját scripted. \n(Hagyd üresen a törléshez) \nInformáció a saját scriptekről itt.
\nSaját leállítási script \nSaját script mely lefut a tűzfal letiltásánál:
Vannak nem mentett változások.\nAlkalmazod vagy elveted?
Felül fogod írni a jelenlegi szabályokat. Folytatod?
A jelszavak nem egyeznek! Próbáld újra.
Válaszd ki a létrehozandó vagy módosítandó profilt
Az Android Firewall profilját a plugin/gomb megváltoztatta. A tűzfal kikapcsolva!
This setting enables or disables Notification Pop-ups when the firewall is modified by Tasker, Locale, Llama, Macrodroid, or the shortcuts themselves.
Ez a beállítás engedélyezi, illetve letiltja az értesítéseket ha az újonnan telepített alkalmazásoknak szükség van Internet-hozzáférésre
The pluging or shortcuts have changed the profile being used by Android Firewall
Hiba történt az androidfirewall mappa elérése közben. Kérlek exportáld ki a szabályokat
Hiba történt az androidfirewall mappa elérése közben. Ellenőrizd, hogy az SD kártya vagy a külső tárhely elérhető-e!
A tűzfal jelszóval védett, nem letiltható.
Az Android Firewall nem kapott root hozzáférést!

This setting makes the app wait for the SDCard scan to be finished before applying rules after reboot. This is needed if you have apps that require data access and you moved them to the SDCard. Please note that this increases the time it takes for the rules to be applied after a reboot.
Ez a beállítás be- vagy kikapcsolja a LAN-támogatást. Ez lehetővé teszi, hogy egy alkalmazás hozzáférjen a LAN-hoz, de az internethez nem.
Nem sikerült elérni az androidfirewall könyvtárat. Kérlek exportáld ki előbb a szabálylistát.

Enabling this will apply the firewall rules on every connectivity change when on Data, WiFi, Roaming, or LAN. This is required for LAN support. Older devices may see performance issues with this enabled.
Az IPv6 támogatás nem elérhető ezen az eszközön.
A bekapcsolásával engedélyezve lesz a más eszközökre történő internetmegosztás.
Enabling this will activate the INPUT chains for iptables. This will allow you to block certain types of communication headed TO your device.
Disabling this will deactivate the INPUT chains for iptables.

Enabling this option will unlock multi-user support. Multi-user support REQUIRES that you use Blacklist for ALL USERS. Multi-user also requires Android 4.1 or greater. Multi-user is not supported on phones.
Multi-user támogatás engedélyezve van. Átállás a feketelista.
A többfelhasználós támogatás le van tiltva és nem te vagy az elsődleges felhasználó. Kérlek kapcsold be minden felhasználónál a többfelhasználós módot.
Enabling this will log all accepted data flowing in and out of your device. This will allow you see where an application sends data to and where it receives data from.
Tűzfal naplózás engedélyezése az elfogadott adatokra.
Nem sikerült beolvasni az interfész(ek) információ(ka)t
A hibajelentés zip fájl nem található.
Hiba az iptables tartalmának törlése közben. Hibakód:
Hiba az ip6tables tartalmának törlése közben. Hibakód:
Nem sikerült telepíteni a bináris fájlt
A kiválasztott szabályfájl sérült vagy hiányzik. Kérlek exportálj egy új fájlt.
There is an error accessing the class information. Please contact the developer.
Hiba történt az androidfirewall mappa elérése közben. Kérlek előbb exportáld ki a szabályokat.
Ha bekapcsolod, a rendszeralkalmazásokat pirossal fogja mutatni.
Ha kikapcsolod, a rendszeralkalmazásokat fehérrel fogja mutatni.

Using Android Firewall
1. Click on Mode to switch between White List and Black List modes. 
2. Mark the applications that you want to block or allow (depending on the selected mode), for each interface. 
3. Open the menu and enable the firewall. If the firewall is already enabled, just select Apply rules. 
The rules will be saved and automatically restored when you restart your phone. 
If you want to check all current iptables rules, select Show rules from the Navigation Drawer.

Widgets
To quickly enable or disable the firewall with a single touch, add the On/Off Widget to your home screen. 
To quickly change profiles or enable/disable the firewall, add the Menu Widget to your home screen.

Firewall logs
If you want to see which applications have been blocked by Android Firewall, open the Settings menu and enable the Log. 
Android Firewall will then log each application blocked. You can check the log by opening the menu and selecting Show log from the Navigation Drawer. 
Some newer devices, most notably the Nexus devices, use NFLOG instead of LOG. Android Firewall now supports both. Devices that use NFLOG now have a pair of services that run in order to catch the data. These services only run when logging is enabled. 
 
Android Firewall supports logging of ACCEPTED packets as well. By logging those packets you can see where apps are sending your data. You can then use that information to block access to certain IPs via the Custom Script option or your HOSTS file.

Password lock
You can set a password lock for Android Firewall by using the Set password option in the Navigation Drawer. 
To remove the password protection, just reset it to blank. 
App search
You can search for a specific app by typing the first few letters of the apps name in the search bar next to the spinner.

Supported Interfaces
Along side the traditional WiFi and Data interfaces, three other interfaces are now supported. Support for VPNs, Roaming, and LANs are available. These are enabled under Settings. 
 
VPN support allows apps to only access the data stream when connected to a VPN. 
 
Roaming support allows apps to access the data stream when you are roaming. 
 
LAN support allows apps to access LAN data but not the Internet. LAN support requries the new Automatic Firewall Rules option in Settings to be enabled. Please refer to the description for more information. 
 
NOTE:Automatic Firewall Rules and LAN support require the Internet permission and Access WiFi State permission in order to access the Subnet and LAN address information for each interface. Android Firewall in no way actually transmits data or accesses the Internet.

Tethering support allows you to tether a laptop/tablet/phone to your device without having to disable the firewall. This is new and improved and no longer requires allowing \"apps that run as root\" and \"kernel\". Bluetooth tethering interfaces are now supported by this setting. \n

Tasker/Locale Support
Android Firewall contains a plugin for Tasker and Locale. The plugin allows those apps to Enable or Disable the firewall and change profiles based on different variables. For more information please read the Tasker instructions under the Profiles Help tab. 
Notifications from Tasker, Locale, and the shortcuts stating changes have been made to the firewall are disabled by default. They can be enabled under Settings.

Multi-user Support\nAndroid Firewall supports multiple users on tablets. Multi-user support requires you to use Blacklist at this time and must be enabled under Settings. Multi-user support uses unique IPTABLES chains for each individual user so each user has control over what can access the data stream. \n

INPUT Chain Support\nAndroid Firewall supports INPUT chains. INPUT chains are used to prevent communication from outside sources. INPUT chains works a little bit differently than the OUTPUT chains in Android Firewall. INPUT chains applies to both WiFi and cellular data connections at the same time since there is no way to apply the rules to a specific interface. INPUT chains works with both Blacklist and Whitelist just like current OUTPUT chains. This feature is designed so that if you deny an app access to Data and INPUT but still want it to work on WiFi it will. For example if you deny a web browser access the Data and INPUT but give it access to WiFi the browser will still function correctly when on WiFi. INPUT chains only work on Android 4.x due to limitations in the older kernels. \n

Other settings
 
IPv6 support is available under Settings for those who use IPv6. 
 
Users can change the apps language to one of the supported languages under Settings.

SDcard support for users who have moved apps to their SDcard. Please read the setting description before enabling. 
 
x86 Support for devices running Intel processors.

Application Shortcuts are available for quick access to enabling or disabling the firewall and all of your profiles. These shortcuts can also be used by apps like Llama and Macrodroid for situation based application. \n

Information
 
Media Server is required for YouTube to function.

Android Firewall can generate error reports in order to gather the information needed to correct issues seen by users. This ability generates 3 files containing device information, but NO personal information, which is then written to your external storage so you can see what is data is being collected.
 
They are kept in a folder called af_error_reports. The files are zipped and the user given the option to e-mail the files to the developer. Please include a detailed description of what you were doing when the issue happened.

Rules Management is the ability to export, import, and delete rules files.
 
All user preferences are stored in the rules file so when you export a rules file you also save your Settings like notification support, log enabled, IPv6 support, and the rest. These files are used to create your profiles as well. 
 
Export Rules exports your current rules and settings. 
Import Rules imports rules and settings from a file. 
Manage Rule Files allows you to delete rules files. 
 
Instructions
 
Export Rules 
 
1. Swipe left to open the Navigation Drawer. 
2. Touch Export Rules. 
3. Enter a name for the export files. 
4. Touch OK to save the file. 
 
The file is stored on whatever your device considers its external storage in a folder named androidfirewall. The file name is the user entered name and '_af.rules' appended to the end. 
 
Import Rules 
 
1. Swipe left to open the Navigation Drawer. 
2. Touch Import Rules. 
3. Touch the rules file you want to import. 
 
After you touch the rules file you want to import, the data is imported and firewall settings are changed and rules applied. 
 
Manage Rule Files 
 
1. Swipe left to open the Navigation Drawer. 
2. Touch Manage Rule Files. 
3. Touch the rules file you want to delete. 
4. You will receive a dialog box to confirm the deletion. 
5. Touch 'No' or 'Yes'. 
 
If you touch 'Yes' the rules file is deleted.

Profiles are used to quickly change the firewall rules and settings. This is a very powerful tool as you may want a totally different set of rules depending on where you are or what network you are on. For example, when at work your rules may be very different compared to when you are home. 
 
Profiles are created from rules files that you have exported so you can swap between them quickly and easily if you ever need more than 5 profiles.
 
Create Profile allows you to choose a rules file and assign those rules and settings to a profile. 
Load Profile allows you to apply a profile. 
Edit Profile Names allows you to edit the names of the profiles in order to make it easier to remember what profile does what. 
 
You can swap profiles in a variety of different ways: 
 
1. Manually load a profile by using Load Profile. 
2. Load a profile by using the dropdown spinner on the main app screen. 
3. Use an app like Tasker or Locale to automatically change the profile based on time, location, or some other variable you choose. 
4. Use the Menu Widget to quickly change profiles from your homescreen. 
 
Instructions
 
Create Profile
 
1. Swipe left to open the Navigation Drawer. 
2. Touch Create Profile. 
3. Touch the profile you wish to create. 
4. Touch the rules file you want assigned to that profile. 
5. Touch another profile if you want to assign another rules files otherwise hit the back key. 
 
Load Profile
 
1. Swipe left to open the Navigation Drawer. 
2. Touch Load Profile. 
3. Touch the profile you wish to apply. 
 
Edit Profile Names
 
1. Swipe left to open the Navigation Drawer. 
2. Touch Edit Profile Names. 
3. Touch the profile you want to rename. 
4. Enter the name for the profile and touch 'OK'. 
5. Continue modifying the names otherwise hit the back key. 
 
Using the Spinner
 
1. Touch the spinner and a drop down with all the profiles appears. 
2. Touch the profile you wish to load. 
 
Using Tasker
 
1. Open Tasker. 
2. Touch the '+' and select the 'First Context' for what will cause the profile change. 
3. After you done setting up your context you will be prompted to 'Enter Task'. 
4. Enter a name for the task if you desire then touch the checkmark. 
5. Touch the '+' and a 'Select Action Category' screen appears. 
6. Touch 'Plugin'. 
7. Touch Android Firewall. 
8. Touch the 'Edit' button. 
9. Select which profile you want Tasker to apply. 
10. Hit the back key once. You may now test the Tasker profile by touching the 'Play' button in the bottom left corner.

Author: Jason Tschohl 
Original Author: Rodrigo Zechin Rosauro 
 http://github.com/skullone/android_firewall 
 
Android Firewall is a fork of DroidWall which is a front-end application for the powerful iptables Linux firewall. It allows you to restrict which applications are permitted to access your data networks.
 
This is the perfect solution if you don't have an unlimited data plan or care about your privacy. 
 
Android Firewall is an open source application under GPL v3. 
 
If you would like to help translate Android Firewall please visit the Crowdin website: 
http://www.crowdin.net/project/android-firewall 
 
Included libraries: 
ActionBarSherlock - Apache License 2.0 
http://actionbarsherlock.com 
Libsuperuser - Apache License 2.0 
http://github.com/Chainfire/libsuperuser

Version 2.3.4
 
 1. Fixed bug where Nav drawer would default back to English if language was manually changed.
 2. Updated Help file information for easier translation.
 3. Added more information to Error Reports to help with troubleshooting. All data is still available for users to look at so they know what is being transmitted.
 4. Added interfaces for new devices.
 5. UI cleanup.
 6. Improved support for XXHDPI devices.
 7. Apps that are uninstalled will now show up at the top of the app list if reinstalled. This only applies to apps uninstalled after this update is installed.
 8. Menu options are now correct after the plugin or a shortcut makes a change to firewall.
 9. Notification icon updated so it looks far better.

Version 2.3.5
 
 1. Fix for VPN issue on KitKat.
 2. Better SDcard Support.
 3. FAQ section added.
 4. Ability to change color of system apps.
 5. Disabled apps no longer appear in the app list.
 6. Added AF settings to error reports that are sent.
A YouTube/ zenestreamelés nem működik! Mit szúrtam el?\nEngedélyezd a "Media Server"-t, hogy elérhesse az internetet\n

Why are logs not showing up?\nLogs depend on a service from AF that collects the data or dmesg to collect the data. Neither option can hold the data forever. So the logs are getting overritten quickly or your kernel does not have the proper modules enabled.\n
Miért nem blokkolod az SMS/MMS-eket vagy telefonhívásokat?\nMert az Iptables-szel nem lehet alacsonyszintű forgalmat blokkolni.\n
Why is some app not showing up in the list?\nThe app either does not require internet permission or the app has been disabled.\n

Why does the app request full permissions to all device features and storage?
This permission is the app simply announcing that it requires root access. Here is more information on the permission: https://plus.google.com/103583939320326217147/posts/T9xnMJEnzf1 
 Giving an app root access means you give it full permissions to all device features and storage. If you do not understand that you need to read this: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_rooting

Why does a firewall app require access to the Internet?\nAF does not require access to the Inernet. However, AF does need that permission in order to properly pull the ip address range for the LAN Support functionality. AF makes no calls to the Internet.\n

How do I report a bug in the app?\nSend an Error Report from within the app (Menu -> Send Error Report) or e-mail me at androidfirewall.developer@gmail.com. Please include the reason why you are sending the report. For example: "The firewall is preventing me from tethering my device" or "The firewall isn\'t blocking any apps." You may also open up a bug report on Github. https://github.com/skullone/android_firewall/issues \n
Meg tudod úgy csinálni, hogy ne kérjen root jogot a programod?\nNem. Az iptables fájl elérését jelenleg csak rootként lehet megtenni.\n

Hozzá tudnád adni ezt az xy funckiót is a programodhoz, hogy istenkirálycsászárcsillámfaszláma legyen?\nTalán. Dobj egy emailt a androidfirewall.developer@gmail.com címemre, vagy a Github-on jelentsd be hibaként. https://github.com/skullone/android_firewall/issues \n
